content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Coastal Services Center (CSC), Gulf Coast Services Center</origin> <origin>Naval Research Laboratory, Stennis Space Center</origin> <pubdate>201205</pubdate> <title>Five Year Mean Surface Chlorophyll Estimates in the Northern Gulf of Mexico for 2005 through 2009</title> <geoform>atlas</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Stennis Space Center, Mississippi</pubplace> <publish>NOAA Gulf Coast Services Center</publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://www.ncddc.noaa.gov/website/DataAtlas/atlas.htm</onlink> <onlink>http://www.csc.noaa.gov/</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>These images were created by combining the mean surface chlorophyll estimates to produce seasonal representations for winter, spring, summer and fall. Winter includes the months of January, February and March; spring includes the months of April, May and June; summer includes the months of July, August and September; fall includes the months of October, November and December. Estimates of surface chlorophyll concentration were originally obtained from the Naval Research Laboratory at the Stennis Space Center (NRL/SSC). NRL/SSC processed MODIS-Aqua satellite imagery covering the Gulf of Mexico, for a 5-year time period from January 2005 through December 2009. The Gulf of Mexico was divided into three regions, western, central and eastern. For purposes of this image, the three regions were joined in ArcMAP 10. The surface chlorophyll estimates were determined using the OC3 algorithm for MODIS (O'Reilly et al., 2000). These estimates were then reclassified into phytoplankton productivity categories in accordance with the Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard (CMECS). There are three CMECS categories under this parameter: oligotrophic (< 5 ug/L), mesotrophic (5 - < 50 ug/L), and eutrophic (> 50 ug/L). The mean surface concentrations for the northern Gulf of Mexico only fall into two of the three categories, oligotrophic (shown as blue) and mesotrophic (shown as green).</abstract> <purpose>This project was undertaken to assess the utility of satellite-derived products and modeled data for resource managers to characterize pelagic habitats in the absence of dense, time series in situ data. There were several steps involved in this process, including: identifying the most useful physicochemical parameters for characterizing the water column; assessing the fit of satellite-derived and modeled data as a proxy for in situ data; evaluating alternative, automated classification methodologies; querying resource managers for product improvement opportunities; and developing a practical example of a management application. Surface chlorophyll estimates were one of the satellite-derived products assessed as a proxy for in situ data.</purpose> <supplinf>The NOAA Gulf Services Center received this data from another federal agency.  Questions regarding the original data collection and/or processing should be directed to that agency (see lineage source citation).</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>200501</begdate> <enddate>200912</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>publication date</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>None Planned</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-98.1</westbc> <eastbc>-81.1</eastbc> <northbc>30.9</northbc> <southbc>25.2</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt> <themekey>oceans</themekey> </theme> <theme> <themekt>Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard, FGDC-STD-018-2012</themekt> <themekey>Chlorophyll</themekey> <themekey>Phytoplankton</themekey> <themekey>Productivity</themekey> </theme> <theme> <themekt>None</themekt> <themekey>Environmental Monitoring</themekey> </theme> <place> <placekt>None</placekt> <placekey>Gulf of Mexico</placekey> <placekey>Texas</placekey> <placekey>Louisiana</placekey> <placekey>Mississippi</placekey> <placekey>Alabama</placekey> <placekey>Western Florida</placekey> </place> <stratum> <stratkt>Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard, FGDC-STD-018-2012</stratkt> <stratkey>Water column</stratkey> <stratkey>Pelagic</stratkey> <stratkey>Sea surface</stratkey> <stratkey>Epipelagic</stratkey> </stratum> </keywords> <accconst>None</accconst> <useconst>None</useconst> <datacred>Naval Research Laboratory, Stennis Space Center, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Gulf Coast Services Center NASA Earth Sciences Group, Stennis Space Center</datacred> <progaff> <progname>National Ocean Service Data Explorer</progname> </progaff> </idinfo> <dataqual> <attracc> <attraccr>Unique values were generated for each image in ArcMAP 10. The unique values were then manually reclassified into appropriate Coastal and Marine Ecological Classification Standard categories.</attraccr> </attracc> <logic>not applicable</logic>
